game.name: C.H.A.O.S. Continuum, The (1994)
game.plot: The year is 2577 and everyone on the Titan colony has suddenly disappeared. The station lies empty and hulking with the exception of a few automated robots which patrol the halls. The sentient computer C.H.A.O.S. is resisting any attempt at interface from the outside. You must take an advanced EVA pod, the Time Pod and shifting through dimensional rifts... arrive at the Titan station to determine what went wrong. Use the probe's interfaces to gain access to computers, databanks and whatever else it will take to crack the access codes on the labs and C.H.A.O.S. itself.The game is presented in a standard first-person adventure, with pressable controls for movement and a center window into the world you explore. Most interface with the world is shown through MPC and Quicktime "live-action" video segments. Arrow Controls are provided for movement as well as a targeting/fire key, a 360 degree view button for any area.
game.groups: Game Engine: Director,Gameplay feature: "Simon says",Theme: Hacking / Pseudohacking
game.emu_command: # This is the configuration file for DOSBox 0.82.12. (Please use the latest version of DOSBox)[CR]# Lines starting with a # are comment lines and are ignored by DOSBox.[CR]# They are used to (briefly) document the effect of each option.[CR]# To write out ALL options, use command 'config -all' with -wc or -writeconf options.[CR][CR][sdl][CR]# fullscreen: Start dosbox directly in fullscreen. (Press ALT-Enter to go back)[CR]# fulldouble: Use double buffering in fullscreen. It can reduce screen flickering, but it can also result in a slow DOSBox.[CR]# fullresolution: What resolution to use for fullscreen: original, desktop or a fixed size (e.g. 1024x768).[CR]# Using your monitor's native resolution with aspect=true might give the best results.[CR]# If you end up with small window on a large screen, try an output different from surface.[CR]# windowresolution: Scale the window to this size IF the output device supports hardware scaling.[CR]# (output=openglnb does not!)[CR]# output: What video system to use for output.[CR]# Possible values: surface, overlay, opengl, openglnb, openglhq, ddraw.[CR]# autolock: Mouse will automatically lock, if you click on the screen. (Press CTRL-F10 to unlock)[CR]# autolock_feedback: Autolock status feedback type, i.e. visual, auditive, none.[CR]# Possible values: none, beep, flash.[CR]# sensitivity: Mouse sensitivity.[CR]# mouse_emulation: When is mouse emulated ?[CR]# integration: when not locked[CR]# locked: when locked[CR]# always: every time[CR]# never: at no time[CR]# If disabled, the mouse position in DOSBox-X is exactly where the host OS reports it.[CR]# When using a high DPI mouse, the emulation of mouse movement can noticeably reduce the[CR]# sensitiveness of your device, i.e. the mouse is slower but more precise.[CR]# Possible values: integration, locked, always, never.[CR]# waitonerror: Wait before closing the console if dosbox has an error.[CR]# priority: Priority levels for dosbox. Second entry behind the comma is for when dosbox is not focused/minimized.[CR]# pause is only valid for the second entry.[CR]# Possible values: lowest, lower, normal, higher, highest, pause.[CR]# mapperfile: File used to load/save the key/event mappings from. Resetmapper only works with the default value.[CR]# usescancodes: Avoid usage of symkeys, might not work on all operating systems.[CR]# overscan: Width of overscan border (0 to 10). (works only if output=openglnb)[CR]# titlebar: Change the string displayed in the DOSBox title bar.[CR]# showmenu: Whether to show the menu bar (if supported). Default true.[CR]fullscreen=false[CR]fulldouble=false[CR]fullresolution=desktop[CR]windowresolution=640x480[CR]output=openglnb[CR]autolock=true[CR]autolock_feedback=none[CR]sensitivity=100[CR]mouse_emulation=locked[CR]waitonerror=true[CR]priority=higher,normal[CR]mapperfile=mapper-0.82.12.map[CR]usescancodes=false[CR]overscan=0[CR]titlebar=eXoDOS[CR]showmenu=false[CR][CR][dosbox][CR]# language: Select another language file.[CR]# title: Additional text to place in the title bar of the window[CR]# dpi aware: Set this option (on by default) to indicate to your OS that DOSBox is DPI aware.[CR]# If it is not set, Windows Vista/7/8/10 and higher may upscale the DOSBox window[CR]# on higher resolution monitors which is probably not what you want.[CR]# keyboard hook: Use keyboard hook (currently only on Windows) to catch special keys and synchronize the keyboard LEDs with the host[CR]# weitek: If set, emulate the Weitek coprocessor. This option only has effect if cputype=386 or cputype=486.[CR]# bochs debug port e9: If set, emulate Bochs debug port E9h. ASCII text written to this I/O port is assumed to be debug output, and logged.[CR]# machine: The type of machine DOSBox tries to emulate.[CR]# Possible values: hercules, cga, cga_mono, cga_rgb, cga_composite, cga_composite2, tandy, pcjr, ega, vgaonly, svga_s3, svga_et3000, svga_et4000, svga_paradise, vesa_nolfb, vesa_oldvbe, amstrad, pc98, pc9801, pc9821, fm_towns, mcga, mda.[CR]# svga lfb base: If nonzero, define the physical memory address of the linear framebuffer.[CR]# pci vga: If set, SVGA is emulated as if a PCI device (when enable pci bus=true)[CR]# vmemdelay: VGA Memory I/O delay in nanoseconds. Set to -1 to use default, 0 to disable.[CR]# Default off. Enable this option (-1 or nonzero) if you are running a game or[CR]# demo that needs slower VGA memory (like that of older ISA hardware) to work properly.[CR]# If your game is not sensitive to VGA RAM I/O speed, then turning on this option[CR]# will do nothing but cause a significant drop in frame rate which is probably not[CR]# what you want. Recommended values -1, 0 to 2000.[CR]SET GAMEDIR=XXGAME_DIRXX[CR]# vmemsize: Amount of video memory in megabytes.[CR]# The maximum resolution and color depth the svga_s3 will be able to display[CR]# is determined by this value.[CR]# 0: 512k (800x600 at 256 colors)[CR]# 1: 1024x768 at 256 colors or 800x600 at 64k colors[CR]# 2: 1600x1200 at 256 colors or 1024x768 at 64k colors or 640x480 at 16M colors[CR]# 4: 1600x1200 at 64k colors or 1024x768 at 16M colors[CR]# 8: up to 1600x1200 at 16M colors[CR]# For build engine games, use more memory than in the list above so it can[CR]# use triple buffering and thus won't flicker.[CR]#[CR]# vmemsizekb: Amount of video memory in kilobytes, in addition to vmemsize[CR]# captures: Directory where things like wave, midi, screenshot get captured.[CR]# capture chroma format: Chroma format to use when capturing to H.264. 'auto' picks the best quality option.[CR]# 4:4:4 Chroma is at full resolution. This provides the best quality, however not widely supported by editing software.[CR]# 4:2:2 Chroma is at half horizontal resolution.[CR]# 4:2:0 Chroma is at quarter resolution, which may cause minor color smearing.[CR]# However, this chroma format is most likely to be compatible with video editing software.[CR]# Possible values: auto, 4:4:4, 4:2:2, 4:2:0.[CR]# capture format: Capture format to use when capturing video. The availability of the format depends on how DOSBox-X was compiled.[CR]# default Use compiled-in default (avi-zmbv)[CR]# avi-zmbv Use DOSBox-style AVI + ZMBV codec with PCM audio[CR]# mpegts-h264 Use MPEG transport stream + H.264 + AAC audio. Resolution & refresh rate changes can be contained[CR]# within one file with this choice, however not all software can support mid-stream format changes.[CR]# Possible values: default, avi-zmbv, mpegts-h264.[CR]# shell environment size: Size of the initial DOSBox shell environment block, in bytes. This does not affect the environment block of sub-processes spawned from the shell.[CR]# This option has no effect unless dynamic kernel allocation is enabled.[CR]# private area size: Set DOSBox-X private memory area size. This area contains private memory structures used by the DOS kernel.[CR]# It is discarded when you boot into another OS. Mainline DOSBox uses 32KB. Testing shows that it is possible[CR]# to run DOSBox with as little as 4KB. If DOSBox-X aborts with error "not enough memory for internal tables"[CR]# then you need to increase this value.[CR]# vga attribute controller mapping: This affects how the attribute controller maps colors, especially in 256-color mode.[CR]# Some SVGA cards handle the attribute controller palette differently than most SVGA cards.[CR]# auto Automatically pick the mapping based on the SVGA chipset.[CR]# 4x4 Split into two 4-bit nibbles, map through AC, recombine. This is standard VGA behavior including clone SVGA cards.[CR]# 4low Split into two 4-bit nibbles, remap only the low 4 bits, recombine. This is standard ET4000 behavior.[CR]#[CR]# NOTES:[CR]# Demoscene executable 'COPPER.EXE' requires the '4low' behavior in order to display line-fading effects[CR]# (including scrolling credits) correctly, else those parts of the demo show up as a blank screen.[CR]#[CR]# 4low behavior is default for ET4000 emulation.[CR]# Possible values: , auto, 4x4, 4low, first16.[CR]# a20: A20 gate emulation mode.[CR]# The on/off/on_fake/off_fake options are intended for testing and debugging DOS development,[CR]# or to emulate obscure hardware, or to work around potential extended memory problems with DOS programs.[CR]# on_fake/off_fake are intended to test whether a program carries out a memory test to ensure the A20[CR]# gate is set as intended (as HIMEM.SYS does). If it goes by the gate bit alone, it WILL crash.[CR]# This parameter is also changeable from the builtin A20GATE command.[CR]# fast Emulate A20 gating by remapping the first 64KB @ 1MB boundary (fast, mainline DOSBox behavior)[CR]# mask Emulate A20 gating by masking memory I/O address (accurate)[CR]# off Lock A20 gate off (Software/OS cannot enable A20)[CR]# on Lock A20 gate on (Software/OS cannot disable A20)[CR]# off_fake Lock A20 gate off but allow bit to toggle (hope your DOS game tests the HMA!)[CR]# on_fake Lock A20 gate on but allow bit to toggle[CR]# turn off a20 gate on boot: If enabled, A20 gate is switched off when booting a guest OS.[CR]# Enabled by default. Recommended for MS-DOS when HIMEM.SYS is not installed in the guest OS.[CR]# If disabled, and MS-DOS does not load HIMEM.SYS, programs and features that rely on the 1MB wraparound will fail.[CR]# isa bus clock: ISA BCLK frequency, used to emulate I/O delay.[CR]# WARNING: In future revisions, PCI/motherboard chipset emulation will allow the guest OS/program to alter this value at runtime.[CR]# std8.3 8.333MHz (typical 386-class or higher)[CR]# std8 8MHz[CR]# std6 6MHz[CR]# std4.77 4.77MHz (precisely 1/3 x 14.31818MHz). Bus frequency of older PC/XT systems.[CR]# oc10 10MHz[CR]# oc12 12MHz[CR]# oc15 15MHz[CR]# oc16 16MHz[CR]# <integer or float> Any integer or floating point value will be used as the clock frequency in Hz[CR]# <integer/integer ratio> If a ratio is given (num/den), the ratio will be used as the clock frequency[CR]# pci bus clock: PCI bus frequency, used to emulate I/O delay.[CR]# WARNING: In future revisions, PCI/motherboard chipset emulation will allow the guest OS/program to alter this value at runtime.[CR]# std33.3 33.333MHz (very common setting on motherboards)[CR]# std30 30MHz (some older mid-1990's Pentium systems)[CR]# std25 25MHz[CR]# <integer or float> Any integer or floating point value will be used as the clock frequency in Hz[CR]# <integer/integer ratio> If a ratio is given (num/den), the ratio will be used as the clock frequency[CR]# call binary on reset: If set, this is the path of a binary blob to load into the ROM BIOS area and execute immediately after CPU reset.[CR]# It will be executed before the BIOS POST routine, only ONCE. The binary blob is expected either to IRET or to[CR]# jump directly to F000:FFF0 to return control to the BIOS.[CR]# This can be used for x86 assembly language experiments and automated testing against the CPU emulation.[CR]# unhandled irq handler: Determines how unhandled IRQs are handled. This may help some errant DOS applications.[CR]# Leave unset for default behavior (simple).[CR]# simple Acknowledge the IRQ, and the master (if slave IRQ)[CR]# mask_isr Acknowledge IRQs in service on master and slave and mask IRQs still in service, to deal with errant handlers (em-dosbox method)[CR]# Possible values: , simple, cooperative_2nd.[CR]# call binary on boot: If set, this is the path of a binary blob to load into the ROM BIOS area and execute immediately before booting the DOS system.[CR]# This can be used for x86 assembly language experiments and automated testing against the CPU emulation.[CR]# rom bios allocation max: Maximum size (top down from 1MB) allowed for ROM BIOS dynamic allocation in KB[CR]# rom bios minimum size: Once ROM BIOS layout is finalized, trim total region down to a minimum amount in KB[CR]# irq delay ns: IRQ delay in nanoseconds. Set to -1 to use default, 0 to disable.[CR]# This is a more precise version of the irqdelay= setting.[CR]# There are some old DOS games and demos that have race conditions with IRQs that need a nonzero value here to work properly.[CR]# iodelay: I/O delay in nanoseconds for I/O port access. Set to -1 to use default, 0 to disable.[CR]# A value of 1000 (1us) is recommended for ISA bus type delays. If your game[CR]# or demo is not sensitive to I/O port and ISA bus timing, you can turn this option off[CR]# (set to 0) to increase game performance.[CR]# iodelay16: I/O delay for 16-bit transfers. -1 to use default, 0 to disable.[CR]# iodelay32: I/O delay for 32-bit transfers. -1 to use default, 0 to disable.[CR]# acpi: ACPI emulation, and what version of the specification to follow.[CR]# WARNING: This option is very experimental at this time and should not be enabled unless you're willing to accept the consequences.[CR]# Intended for use with ACPI-aware OSes including Linux and Windows 98/ME. This option will also slightly reduce available[CR]# system memory to make room for the ACPI tables, just as real BIOSes do, and reserve an IRQ for ACPI functions.[CR]# Possible values: off, 1.0, 1.0b, 2.0, 2.0a, 2.0b, 2.0c, 3.0, 3.0a, 3.0b, 4.0, 4.0a, 5.0, 5.0a, 6.0.[CR]# acpi rsd ptr location: Where to store the Root System Description Pointer structure. You can have it stored in the ROM BIOS area, or the Extended Bios Data Area.[CR]# Possible values: auto, bios, ebda.[CR]# acpi sci irq: IRQ to assign as ACPI system control interrupt. set to -1 to automatically assign.[CR]# acpi iobase: I/O port base for the ACPI device Power Management registers. Set to 0 for automatic assignment.[CR]# acpi reserved size: Amount of memory at top to reserve for ACPI structures and tables. Set to 0 for automatic assignment.[CR]# memsize: Amount of memory DOSBox has in megabytes.[CR]# This value is best left at its default to avoid problems with some games,[CR]# though few games might require a higher value.[CR]# There is generally no speed advantage when raising this value.[CR]# Programs that use 286 protected mode like Windows 3.0 in Standard Mode may crash with more than 15MB.[CR]# memsizekb: Amount of memory DOSBox has in kilobytes.[CR]# This value should normally be set to 0.[CR]# If nonzero, it is added to the memsize parameter.[CR]# Finer grained control of total memory may be useful in[CR]# emulating ancient DOS machines with less than 640KB of[CR]# RAM or early 386 systems with odd extended memory sizes.[CR]# dos mem limit: Limit DOS conventional memory to this amount. Does not affect extended memory.[CR]# Setting this option to a value in the range 636-639 can be used to simulate modern BIOSes[CR]# that maintain an EBDA (Extended BIOS Data Area) at the top of conventional memory.[CR]# You may also play with this option for diagnostic purposes or to stress test DOS programs in limited memory setups.[CR]#[CR]# A few DOS games & demos require this option to be set:[CR]# Majic 12 "Show": If UMBs are enabled, set this option to 639 to avoid MCB chain corruption error.[CR]# isa memory hole at 512kb: If set, emulate an ISA memory hole at the 512KB to 640KB area (0x80000-0x9FFFF).[CR]# memalias: Memory aliasing emulation, in number of valid address bits.[CR]# . Many 386/486 class motherboards and processors prior to 1995[CR]# suffered from memory aliasing for various technical reasons. If the software you are[CR]# trying to run assumes aliasing, or otherwise plays cheap tricks with paging,[CR]# enabling this option can help. Note that enabling this option can cause slight performance degredation. Set to 0 to disable.[CR]# Recommended values when enabled:[CR]# 24: 16MB aliasing. Common on 386SX systems (CPU had 24 external address bits)[CR]# or 386DX and 486 systems where the CPU communicated directly with the ISA bus (A24-A31 tied off)[CR]# 26: 64MB aliasing. Some 486s had only 26 external address bits, some motherboards tied off A26-A31[CR]# pc-98 int 1b fdc timer wait: If set, INT 1Bh floppy access will wait for the timer to count down before returning.[CR]# This is needed for Ys II to run without crashing.[CR]# pc-98 pic init to read isr: If set, the programmable interrupt controllers are initialized by default (if PC-98 mode)[CR]# so that the in-service interrupt status can be read immediately. There seems to be a common[CR]# convention in PC-98 games to program and/or assume this mode for cooperative interrupt handling.[CR]# This option is enabled by default for best compatibility with PC-98 games.[CR]# pc-98 fm board: In PC-98 mode, selects the FM music board to emulate.[CR]# Possible values: auto, off, false, board26k, board86, board86c.[CR]# pc-98 fm board irq: If set, helps to determine the IRQ of the FM board. A setting of zero means to auto-determine the IRQ.[CR]# pc-98 fm board io port: If set, helps to determine the base I/O port of the FM board. A setting of zero means to auto-determine the port number.[CR]# pc-98 sound bios: Set Sound BIOS enabled bit in MEMSW 4 for some games that require it.[CR]# TODO: Real emulation of PC-9801-26K/86 Sound BIOS[CR]# pc-98 buffer page flip: If set, the game's request to page flip will be delayed to vertical retrace, which can eliminate tearline artifacts.[CR]# Note that this is NOT the behavior of actual hardware. This option is provided for the user's preference.[CR]# pc-98 enable 16-color: Allow 16-color graphics mode if set, disable if not set[CR]# pc-98 enable grcg: Allow GRCG graphics functions if set, disable if not set[CR]# pc-98 enable egc: Allow EGC graphics functions if set, disable if not set[CR]# pc-98 enable 188 user cg: Allow 188+ user-defined CG cells if set[CR]# pc-98 start gdc at 5mhz: Start GDC at 5MHz if set, 2.5MHz if clear. May be required for some games.[CR]# pc-98 allow scanline effect: If set, PC-98 emulation will allow the DOS application to enable the 'scanline effect'[CR]# in 200-line graphics modes upconverted to 400-line raster display. When enabled, odd[CR]# numbered scanlines are blanked instead of doubled[CR]# pc-98 bus mouse: Enable PC-98 bus mouse emulation. Disabling this option does not disable INT 33h emulation.[CR]# pc-98 video mode: Specify the preferred PC-98 video mode.[CR]# Valid values are 15, 24, or 31 for each specific horizontal refresh rate on the platform.[CR]# 24khz is default and best supported at this time.[CR]# 15khz is not implemented at this time.[CR]# 31khz is experimental at this time.[CR]# Possible values: , 24khz, 31khz, 15khz.[CR]# pc-98 timer master frequency: 8254 timer clock frequency (NEC PC-98). Depending on the CPU frequency the clock frequency is one of two common values.[CR]# If your setting is neither of the below the closest appropriate value will be chosen.[CR]# This setting affects the master clock rate that DOS applications must divide down from to program the timer[CR]# at the correct rate, which affects timer interrupt, PC speaker, and the COM1 RS-232C serial port baud rate.[CR]# 8MHz is treated as an alias for 4MHz and 10MHz is treated as an alias for 5MHz.[CR]# 0: Use default (auto)[CR]# 4: 1.996MHz (as if 4MHz or multiple thereof CPU clock)[CR]# 5: 2.457MHz (as if 5MHz or multiple thereof CPU clock)[CR]# pc-98 allow 4 display partition graphics: According to NEC graphics controller documentation, graphics mode is supposed to support only[CR]# 2 display partitions. Some games rely on hardware flaws that allowed 4 partitions.[CR]# -1: Default (choose automatically)[CR]# 0: Disable[CR]# 1: Enable[CR]# pc-98 force ibm keyboard layout: Force to use a default keyboard layout like IBM US-English for PC-98 emulation.[CR]# Will only work with apps and games using BIOS for keyboard.[CR]# vga bios size override: VGA BIOS size override. Override the size of the VGA BIOS (normally 32KB in compatible or 12KB in non-compatible).[CR]# video bios dont duplicate cga first half rom font: If set, save 4KB of EGA/VGA ROM space by pointing to the copy in the ROM BIOS of the first 128 chars[CR]# video bios always offer 14-pixel high rom font: If set, video BIOS will always carry the 14-pixel ROM font. If clear, 14-pixel rom font will not be offered except for EGA/VGA emulation.[CR]# video bios always offer 16-pixel high rom font: If set, video BIOS will always carry the 16-pixel ROM font. If clear, 16-pixel rom font will not be offered except for VGA emulation.[CR]# video bios enable cga second half rom font: If set, and emulating CGA/PCjr/Tandy, automatically provide the second half of the 8x8 ROM font.[CR]# This setting is ignored for EGA/VGA emulation. If not set, you will need a utility like GRAFTABL.COM to load the second half of the ROM font for graphics.[CR]# NOTE: if you disable the 14 & 16 pixel high font AND the second half when machine=cga, you will disable video bios completely.[CR]# forcerate: Force the VGA framerate to a specific value(ntsc, pal, or specific hz), no matter what[CR]# sierra ramdac: Whether or not to emulate a Sierra or compatible RAMDAC at port 3C6h-3C9h.[CR]# Some DOS games expect to access port 3C6h to enable highcolor/truecolor SVGA modes on older chipsets.[CR]# Disable if you wish to emulate SVGA hardware that lacks a RAMDAC or (depending on the chipset) does[CR]# not emulate a RAMDAC that is accessible through port 3C6h. This option has no effect for non-VGA video hardware.[CR]# sierra ramdac lock 565: When emulating High Sierra highcolor RAMDAC, assume 5:6:5 at all times if set. Else,[CR]# bit 6 of the DAC command selects between 5:5:5 and 5:6:5. Set this option for demos or[CR]# games that got the command byte wrong (MFX Transgrassion 2) or any other demo that is[CR]# not rendering highcolor 16bpp correctly.[CR]# page flip debug line: VGA debugging switch. If set, an inverse line will be drawn on the exact scanline that the CRTC display offset registers were written.[CR]# This can be used to help diagnose whether or not the DOS game is page flipping properly according to vertical retrace if the display on-screen is flickering.[CR]# vertical retrace poll debug line: VGA debugging switch. If set, an inverse green dotted line will be drawn on the exact scanline that the CRTC status port (0x3DA) was read.[CR]# This can be used to help diagnose whether the DOS game is propertly waiting for vertical retrace.[CR]# cgasnow: When machine=cga, determines whether or not to emulate CGA snow in 80x25 text mode[CR]# vga 3da undefined bits: VGA status port 3BA/3DAh only defines bits 0 and 3. This setting allows you to assign a bit pattern to the undefined bits.[CR]# The purpose of this hack is to deal with demos that read and handle port 3DAh in ways that might crash if all are zero.[CR]# By default, this value is zero.[CR]# unmask timer on int 10 setmode: If set, INT 10h will unmask IRQ 0 (timer) when setting video modes.[CR]# unmask keyboard on int 16 read: If set, INT 16h will unmask IRQ 1 (keyboard) when asked to read keyboard input.[CR]# int16 keyboard polling undocumented cf behavior: If set, INT 16h function AH=01h will also set/clear the carry flag depending on whether input was available.[CR]# There are some old DOS games and demos that rely on this behavior to sense keyboard input, and this behavior[CR]# has been verified to occur on some old (early 90s) BIOSes.[CR]# allow port 92 reset: If set (default), allow the application to reset the CPU through port 92h[CR]# enable port 92: Emulate port 92h (PS/2 system control port A). If you want to emulate a system that pre-dates the PS/2, set to 0.[CR]# enable 1st dma controller: Emulate 1st (AT) DMA controller (default). Set to 0 if you wish to emulate a system that lacks DMA (PCjr and some Tandy systems)[CR]# enable 2nd dma controller: Emulate 2nd (AT) DMA controller (default). Set to 0 if you wish to emulate a PC/XT system without 16-bit DMA.[CR]# Note: mainline DOSBox automatically disables 16-bit DMA when machine=cga or machine=hercules, while DOSBox-X does not.[CR]# allow dma address decrement: If set, allow increment & decrement modes as specified in the 8237 datasheet.[CR]# If clear, always increment the address (as if to emulate clone 8237 implementations that skipped the inc/dec bit).[CR]# enable 128k capable 16-bit dma: If true, DMA controller emulation models ISA hardware that permits 16-bit DMA to span 128KB.[CR]# If false, DMA controller emulation models PCI hardware that limits 16-bit DMA to 64KB boundaries.[CR]# If auto, the choice is made according to other factors in hardware emulation[CR]# Possible values: true, false, 1, 0, auto.[CR]# enable dma extra page registers: If set, emulate the extra page registers (I/O ports 0x80, 0x84-0x86, 0x88, 0x8C-0x8E), like actual hardware.[CR]# Note that mainline DOSBox behavior is to NOT emulate these registers.[CR]# dma page registers write-only: Normally (on AT hardware) the DMA page registers are read/write. Set this option if you want to emulate PC/XT hardware where the page registers are write-only.[CR]# cascade interrupt never in service: If set, PIC emulation will never mark cascade interrupt as in service. This is OFF by default. It is a hack for troublesome games.[CR]# cascade interrupt ignore in service: If set, PIC emulation will allow slave pic interrupts even if the cascade interrupt is still "in service". This is OFF by default. It is a hack for troublesome games.[CR]# enable slave pic: Enable slave PIC (IRQ 8-15). Set this to 0 if you want to emulate a PC/XT type arrangement with IRQ 0-7 and no IRQ 2 cascade.[CR]# enable pc nmi mask: Enable PC/XT style NMI mask register (0xA0). Note that this option conflicts with the secondary PIC and will be ignored if the slave PIC is enabled.[CR]# rom bios 8x8 CGA font: If set, or mainline compatible bios mapping, a legacy 8x8 CGA font (first 128 characters) is stored at 0xF000:0xFA6E. DOS programs that do not use INT 10h to locate fonts might require that font to be located there.[CR]# rom bios video parameter table: If set, or mainline compatible bios mapping, DOSBox will emulate the video parameter table and assign that to INT 1Dh. If clear, table will not be provided.[CR]# allow more than 640kb base memory: If set, and space is available, allow conventional memory to extend past 640KB.[CR]# For example, if machine=cga, conventional memory can extend out to 0xB800 and provide up to 736KB of RAM.[CR]# This allows you to emulate PC/XT style memory extensions.[CR]# vesa lfb base scanline adjust: If non-zero, the VESA BIOS will report the linear framebuffer offset by this many scanlines.[CR]# This does not affect the linear framebuffer's location. It only affects the linear framebuffer[CR]# location reported by the VESA BIOS. Set to nonzero for DOS games with sloppy VESA graphics pointer management.[CR]# MFX "Melvindale" (1996): Set this option to 2 to center the picture properly.[CR]# vesa map non-lfb modes to 128kb region: If set, VESA BIOS SVGA modes will be set to map 128KB of video memory to A0000-BFFFF instead of[CR]# 64KB at A0000-AFFFF. This does not affect the SVGA window size or granularity.[CR]# Some games or demoscene productions assume that they can render into the next SVGA window/bank[CR]# by writing to video memory beyond the current SVGA window address and will not appear correctly[CR]# without this option.[CR]# allow hpel effects: If set, allow the DOS demo or program to change the horizontal pel (panning) register per scanline.[CR]# Some early DOS demos use this to create waving or sinus effects on the picture. Not very many VGA[CR]# chipsets allow this, so far, only ATI chipsets are known to support this effect. Disabled by default.[CR]# allow hretrace effects: If set, allow the DOS demo or program to make the picture wavy by playing with the 'start horizontalretrace' register of the CRTC during the active picture. Some early DOS demos (Copper by Surprise!productions) need this option set for some demo effects to work. Disabled by default.[CR]# hretrace effect weight: If emulating hretrace effects, this parameter adds 'weight' to the offset to smooth it out.[CR]# the larger the number, the more averaging is applied. This is intended to emulate the inertia[CR]# of the electron beam in a CRT monitor[CR]# vesa modelist cap: IF nonzero, the VESA modelist is capped so that it contains no more than the specified number of video modes.[CR]# Set this option to a value between 8 to 32 if the DOS application has problems with long modelists or a fixed[CR]# buffer for querying modes. Such programs may crash if given the entire modelist supported by DOSBox-X.[CR]# Warcraft II by Blizzard ................ Set to a value between 8 and 16. This game has a fixed buffer that it[CR]# reads the modelist into. DOSBox-X's normal modelist is too long and[CR]# the game will overrun the buffer and crash without this setting.[CR]# vesa modelist width limit: IF nonzero, VESA modes with horizontal resolution higher than the specified pixel count will not be listed.[CR]# This is another way the modelist can be capped for DOS applications that have trouble with long modelists.[CR]# vesa modelist height limit: IF nonzero, VESA modes with vertical resolution higher than the specified pixel count will not be listed.[CR]# This is another way the modelist can be capped for DOS applications that have trouble with long modelists.[CR]# vesa vbe put modelist in vesa information: If set, the VESA modelist is placed in the VESA information structure itself when the DOS application[CR]# queries information on the VESA BIOS. Setting this option may help with some games, though it limits[CR]# the mode list reported to the DOS application.[CR]# vesa vbe 1.2 modes are 32bpp: If set, truecolor (16M color) VESA BIOS modes in the 0x100-0x11F range are 32bpp. If clear, they are 24bpp.[CR]# Some DOS games and demos assume one bit depth or the other and do not enumerate VESA BIOS modes, which is why this[CR]# option exists.[CR]# allow low resolution vesa modes: If set, allow low resolution VESA modes (320x200x16/24/32bpp and so on). You could set this to false to simulate[CR]# SVGA hardware with a BIOS that does not support the lowres modes for testing purposes.[CR]# allow 32bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 32bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 24bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 24bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 16bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 16bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 15bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 15bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 8bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 8bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 4bpp vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 4bpp VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow 4bpp packed vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with 4bpp packed VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# allow tty vesa modes: If the DOS game or demo has problems with text VESA modes, set to 'false'[CR]# double-buffered line compare: This setting affects the VGA Line Compare register. Set to false (default value) to emulate most VGA behavior[CR]# Set to true for the value to latch once at the start of the frame.[CR]# ignore vblank wraparound: DOSBox-X can handle active display properly if games or demos reprogram vertical blanking to end in the active picture area.[CR]# If the wraparound handling prevents the game from displaying properly, set this to false. Out of bounds vblank values will be ignored.[CR]#[CR]# enable vga resize delay: If the DOS game you are running relies on certain VGA raster tricks that affect active display area, enable this option.[CR]# This adds a delay between VGA mode changes and window updates. It also means that if you are capturing a demo or game,[CR]# that your capture will also show a few garbled frames at any point mode changes occur, which is why this option is disabled[CR]# by default. If you intend to run certain DOS games and demos like DoWhackaDo, enable this option.[CR]# resize only on vga active display width increase: If set, changes to the Display End register of the CRTC do not trigger DOSBox to resize it's window[CR]# IF the value written is less than the current value. Some demos like DoWhackaDo need this option set[CR]# because of the way it's raster effects work. If the DOSBox window rapidly changes size during a demo[CR]# try setting this option. Else, leave it turned off. Changes to other VGA CRTC registers will trigger[CR]# a DOSBox mode change as normal regardless of this setting.[CR]# enable pci bus: Enable PCI bus emulation[CR]# vga palette update on full load: If set, all three bytes of the palette entry must be loaded before taking the color,[CR]# which is fairly typical SVGA behavior. If not set, partial changes are allowed.[CR]# ignore odd-even mode in non-cga modes: Some demoscene productions use VGA Mode X but accidentally enable odd/even mode.[CR]# Setting this option can correct for that and render the demo properly.[CR]# This option forces VGA emulation to ignore odd/even mode except in text and CGA modes.[CR]language=[CR]title=[CR]dpi aware=true[CR]keyboard load=true[CR]ignore odd-even mode in non-cga modes=false[CR][CR][render][CR]# frameskip: How many frames DOSBox skips before drawing one.[CR]# aspect: Aspect ratio correction mode. Can be set to the following values:[CR]# 'false' (default):[CR]# 'direct3d'/opengl outputs: image is simply scaled to full window/fullscreen size, possibly resulting in disproportional image[CR]# 'surface' output: it does no aspect ratio correction (default), resulting in disproportional images if VGA mode pixel ratio is not 4:3[CR]# 'true':[CR]# 'direct3d'/opengl outputs: uses output driver functions to scale / pad image with black bars, correcting output to proportional 4:3 image[CR]# In most cases image degradation should not be noticeable (it all depends on the video adapter and how much the image is upscaled).[CR]# Should have none to negligible impact on performance, mostly being done in hardware[CR]# 'surface' output: inherits old DOSBox aspect ratio correction method (adjusting rendered image line count to correct output to 4:3 ratio)[CR]# Due to source image manipulation this mode does not mix well with scalers, i.e. multiline scalers like hq2x/hq3x will work poorly[CR]# Slightly degrades visual image quality. Has a tiny impact on performance[CR]# When using xBRZ scaler with 'surface' output, aspect ratio correction is done by the scaler itself, so none of the above apply[CR]# Possible values: false, true, 0, 1, yes, no, nearest, bilinear.[CR]# char9: Allow 9-pixel wide text mode fonts.[CR]# doublescan: If set, doublescanned output emits two scanlines for each source line, in the[CR]# same manner as the actual VGA output (320x200 is rendered as 640x400 for example).[CR]# If clear, doublescanned output is rendered at the native source resolution (320x200 as 320x200).[CR]# This affects the raster PRIOR to the software or hardware scalers. Choose wisely.[CR]#[CR]# scaler: Scaler used to enlarge/enhance low resolution modes. If 'forced' is appended,[CR]# then the scaler will be used even if the result might not be desired.[CR]# Possible values: none, normal2x, normal3x, normal4x, normal5x, advmame2x, advmame3x, advinterp2x, advinterp3x, hq2x, hq3x, 2xsai, super2xsai, supereagle, tv2x, tv3x, rgb2x, rgb3x, scan2x, scan3x, hardware_none, hardware2x, hardware3x, hardware4x, hardware5x, xbrz, xbrz_bilinear.[CR]# xbrz slice: Number of screen lines to process in single xBRZ scaler taskset task, affects xBRZ performance, 16 is the default[CR]# xbrz fixed scale factor: To use fixed xBRZ scale factor (i.e. to attune performance), set it to 2-6, 0 - use automatic calculation (default)[CR]# xbrz max scale factor: To cap maximum xBRZ scale factor used (i.e. to attune performance), set it to 2-6, 0 - use scaler allowed maximum (default)[CR]# autofit: Best fits image to window[CR]# - Intended for output = direct3d, fullresolution=0x0, aspect=true[CR]frameskip=0[CR]aspect=true[CR]char9=true[CR]doublescan=false[CR]scaler=normal2x[CR]xbrz slice=16[CR]xbrz fixed scale factor=0[CR]xbrz max scale factor=0[CR]autofit=true[CR][CR][vsync][CR]# vsyncmode: Synchronize vsync timing to the host display. Requires calibration within dosbox.[CR]# Possible values: off, on, force, host.[CR]# vsyncrate: Vsync rate used if vsync is enabled. Ignored if vsyncmode is set to host (win32).[CR]# Possible values:.[CR]vsyncmode=off[CR]vsyncrate=75[CR][CR][cpu][CR]# core: CPU Core used in emulation. auto will switch to dynamic if available and appropriate.[CR]# WARNING: Do not use dynamic or auto setting core with Windows 95 or other preemptive[CR]# multitasking OSes with protected mode paging, you should use the normal core instead.[CR]# Possible values: auto, dynamic, normal, full, simple.[CR]# fpu: Enable FPU emulation[CR]# segment limits: Enforce segment limits[CR]# double fault: Emulate double fault exception[CR]# reset on triple fault: Reset CPU on triple fault condition (failure to handle double fault)[CR]# always report double fault: Always report (to log file) double faults if set. Else, a double fault is reported only once. Set this option for debugging purposes.[CR]# always report triple fault: Always report (to log file) triple faults if set. Else, a triple fault is reported only once. Set this option for debugging purposes.[CR]# enable msr: Allow RDMSR/WRMSR instructions. This option is only meaningful when cputype=pentium.[CR]# WARNING: Leaving this option enabled while installing Windows 95/98/ME can cause crashes.[CR]# enable cmpxchg8b: Enable Pentium CMPXCHG8B instruction. Enable this explicitly if using software that uses this instruction.[CR]# You must enable this option to run Windows ME because portions of the kernel rely on this instruction.[CR]# ignore undefined msr: Ignore RDMSR/WRMSR on undefined registers. Normally the CPU will fire an Invalid Opcode exception in that case.[CR]# This option is off by default, enable if using software or drivers that assumes the presence of[CR]# certain MSR registers without checking. If you are using certain versions of the 3Dfx glide drivers for MS-DOS[CR]# you will need to set this to TRUE as 3Dfx appears to have coded GLIDE2.OVL to assume the presence[CR]# of Pentium Pro/Pentium II MTRR registers.[CR]# WARNING: Leaving this option enabled while installing Windows 95/98/ME can cause crashes.[CR]# interruptible rep string op: if nonzero, REP string instructions (LODS/MOVS/STOS/INS/OUTS) are interruptible (by interrupts or other events).[CR]# if zero, REP string instructions are carried out in full before processing events and interrupts.[CR]# Set to -1 for a reasonable default setting based on cpu type and other configuration.[CR]# A setting of 0 can improve emulation speed at the expense of emulation accuracy.[CR]# A nonzero setting (1-8) may be needed for DOS games and demos that use the IRQ 0 interrupt to play digitized samples[CR]# while doing VGA palette animation at the same time (use case of REP OUTS), where the non-interruptible version[CR]# would cause an audible drop in audio pitch.[CR]# dynamic core cache block size: dynamic core cache block size. default value is 32. change this value carefully.[CR]# according to forum discussion, setting this to 1 can aid debugging, however doing so[CR]# also causes problems with 32-bit protected mode DOS games and reduces the performance[CR]# of the dynamic core.[CR]#[CR]# cputype: CPU Type used in emulation. auto emulates a 486 which tolerates Pentium instructions.[CR]# Possible values: auto, 8086, 8086_prefetch, 80186, 80186_prefetch, 286, 286_prefetch, 386, 386_prefetch, 486old, 486old_prefetch, 486, 486_prefetch, pentium, pentium_mmx, ppro_slow.[CR]# cycles: Amount of instructions DOSBox tries to emulate each millisecond.[CR]# Setting this value too high results in sound dropouts and lags.[CR]# Cycles can be set in 3 ways:[CR]# 'auto' tries to guess what a game needs.[CR]# It usually works, but can fail for certain games.[CR]# 'fixed #number' will set a fixed amount of cycles. This is what you usually[CR]# need if 'auto' fails (Example: fixed 4000).[CR]# 'max' will allocate as much cycles as your computer is able to[CR]# handle.[CR]# Possible values: auto, fixed, max.[CR]# cycleup: Amount of cycles to decrease/increase with keycombos.(CTRL-F11/CTRL-F12)[CR]# cycledown: Setting it lower than 100 will be a percentage.[CR]# use dynamic core with paging on: Dynamic core is NOT compatible with the way page faults in the guest are handled in DosBox-X.[CR]# Windows 9x may crash with paging on if dynamic core is enabled. Enable at your own risk.[CR]#[CR]# ignore opcode 63: When debugging, do not report illegal opcode 0x63.[CR]# Enable this option to ignore spurious errors while debugging from within Windows 3.1/9x/ME[CR]# apmbios: Emulate Advanced Power Management BIOS calls[CR]# apmbios pnp: If emulating ISA PnP BIOS, announce APM BIOS in PnP enumeration.[CR]# Warning: this can cause Windows 95 OSR2 and later to enumerate the APM BIOS twice and cause problems.[CR]# apmbios version: What version of the APM BIOS specification to emulate.[CR]# You will need at least APM BIOS v1.1 for emulation to work with Windows 95/98/ME[CR]# Possible values: auto, 1.0, 1.1, 1.2.[CR]# apmbios allow realmode: Allow guest OS to connect from real mode.[CR]# apmbios allow 16-bit protected mode: Allow guest OS to connect from 16-bit protected mode.[CR]# apmbios allow 32-bit protected mode: Allow guest OS to connect from 32-bit protected mode.[CR]# If you want power management in Windows 95/98/ME (beyond using the APM to shutdown the computer) you MUST enable this option.[CR]# Windows 95/98/ME does not support the 16-bit real and protected mode APM BIOS entry points.[CR]# Please note at this time that 32-bit APM is unstable under Windows ME[CR]# integration device: Enable DOSBox integration I/O device. This can be used by the guest OS to match mouse pointer position, for example. EXPERIMENTAL![CR]# integration device pnp: List DOSBox integration I/O device as part of ISA PnP enumeration. This has no purpose yet.[CR]# isapnpbios: Emulate ISA Plug & Play BIOS. Enable if using DOSBox to run a PnP aware DOS program or if booting Windows 9x.[CR]# Do not disable if Windows 9x is configured around PnP devices, you will likely confuse it.[CR]# realbig16: Allow the B (big) bit in real mode. If set, allow the DOS program to set the B bit,[CR]# then jump to realmode with B still set (aka Huge Unreal mode). Needed for Project Angel.[CR]core=auto[CR]fpu=true[CR]segment limits=true[CR]double fault=true[CR]reset on triple fault=true[CR]always report double fault=false[CR]always report triple fault=false[CR]enable msr=true[CR]enable cmpxchg8b=true[CR]ignore undefined msr=false[CR]interruptible rep string op=-1[CR]dynamic core cache block size=32[CR]cputype=auto[CR]cycles=auto[CR]cycleup=10[CR]cycledown=20[CR]use dynamic core with paging on=false[CR]ignore opcode 63=true[CR]apmbios=true[CR]apmbios pnp=false[CR]apmbios version=auto[CR]apmbios allow realmode=true[CR]apmbios allow 16-bit protected mode=true[CR]apmbios allow 32-bit protected mode=true[CR]integration device=false[CR]integration device pnp=false[CR]isapnpbios=true[CR]realbig16=false[CR][CR][keyboard][CR]# aux: Enable emulation of the 8042 auxiliary port. PS/2 mouse emulation requires this to be enabled.[CR]# You should enable this if you will be running Windows ME or any other OS that does not use the BIOS to receive mouse events.[CR]# allow output port reset: If set (default), allow the application to reset the CPU through the keyboard controller.[CR]# This option is required to allow Windows ME to reboot properly, whereas Windows 9x and earlier[CR]# will reboot without this option using INT 19h[CR]# controllertype: Type of keyboard controller (and keyboard) attached.[CR]# auto Automatically pick according to machine type[CR]# at AT (PS/2) type keyboard[CR]# xt IBM PC/XT type keyboard[CR]# pcjr IBM PCjr type keyboard (only if machine=pcjr)[CR]# pc98 PC-98 keyboard emulation (only if machine=pc98)[CR]# Possible values: auto, at, xt, pcjr, pc98.[CR]# auxdevice: Type of PS/2 mouse attached to the AUX port[CR]# Possible values: none, 2button, 3button, intellimouse, intellimouse45.[CR]aux=true[CR]allow output port reset=true[CR]controllertype=auto[CR]auxdevice=intellimouse[CR][CR][pci][CR]# voodoo: Enable VOODOO support.[CR]# Possible values: false, software, opengl, auto.[CR]voodoo=auto[CR][CR][mixer][CR]# nosound: Enable silent mode, sound is still emulated though.[CR]# sample accurate: Enable sample accurate mixing, at the expense of some emulation performance. Enable this option for DOS games and demos that[CR]# require such accuracy for correct Tandy/OPL output including digitized speech. This option can also help eliminate minor[CR]# errors in Gravis Ultrasound emulation that result in random echo/attenuation effects.[CR]# swapstereo: Swaps the left and right stereo channels.[CR]# rate: Mixer sample rate, setting any device's rate higher than this will probably lower their sound quality.[CR]# Possible values: 44100, 48000, 32000, 22050, 16000, 11025, 8000, 49716.[CR]# blocksize: Mixer block size, larger blocks might help sound stuttering but sound will also be more lagged.[CR]# Possible values: 1024, 2048, 4096, 8192, 512, 256.[CR]# prebuffer: How many milliseconds of data to keep on top of the blocksize.[CR]nosound=false[CR]sample accurate=false[CR]swapstereo=false[CR]rate=44100[CR]blocksize=1024[CR]prebuffer=20[CR][CR][midi][CR]# mpu401: Type of MPU-401 to emulate.[CR]# Possible values: intelligent, uart, none.[CR]# mididevice: Device that will receive the MIDI data from MPU-401.[CR]# Possible values: default, win32, alsa, oss, coreaudio, coremidi, mt32, synth, timidity, none.[CR]# midiconfig: Special configuration options for the device driver. This is usually the id of the device you want to use.[CR]# or in the case of coreaudio or synth, you can specify a soundfont here.[CR]# When using a Roland MT-32 rev. 0 as midi output device, some games may require a delay in order to prevent 'buffer overflow' issues.[CR]# In that case, add 'delaysysex', for example: midiconfig=2 delaysysex[CR]# See the README/Manual for more details.[CR]# samplerate: Sample rate for MIDI synthesizer, if applicable.[CR]# Possible values: 44100, 48000, 32000, 22050, 16000, 11025, 8000, 49716.[CR]# mpuirq: MPU-401 IRQ. -1 to automatically choose.[CR]# mt32.reverse.stereo: Reverse stereo channels for MT-32 output[CR]# Possible values: off, on.[CR]# mt32.verbose: MT-32 debug logging[CR]# Possible values: off, on.[CR]# mt32.thread: MT-32 rendering in separate thread[CR]# Possible values: off, on.[CR]# mt32.dac: MT-32 DAC input emulation mode[CR]# Nice = 0 - default[CR]# Produces samples at double the volume, without tricks.[CR]# Higher quality than the real devices[CR]#[CR]# Pure = 1[CR]# Produces samples that exactly match the bits output from the emulated LA32.[CR]# Nicer overdrive characteristics than the DAC hacks (it simply clips samples within range)[CR]# Much less likely to overdrive than any other mode.[CR]# Half the volume of any of the other modes, meaning its volume relative to the reverb[CR]# output when mixed together directly will sound wrong. So, reverb level must be lowered.[CR]# Perfect for developers while debugging :)[CR]#[CR]# GENERATION1 = 2[CR]# Re-orders the LA32 output bits as in early generation MT-32s (according to Wikipedia).[CR]# Bit order at DAC (where each number represents the original LA32 output bit number, and XX means the bit is always low):[CR]# 15 13 12 11 10 09 08 07 06 05 04 03 02 01 00 XX[CR]#[CR]# GENERATION2 = 3[CR]# Re-orders the LA32 output bits as in later geneerations (personally confirmed on my CM-32L - KG).[CR]# Bit order at DAC (where each number represents the original LA32 output bit number):[CR]# 15 13 12 11 10 09 08 07 06 05 04 03 02 01 00 14[CR]#[CR]# Possible values: 0, 1, 2, 3, auto.[CR]# mt32.reverb.mode: MT-32 reverb mode[CR]# Possible values: 0, 1, 2, 3, auto.[CR]# mt32.reverb.time: MT-32 reverb decaying time[CR]# Possible values: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.[CR]# mt32.reverb.level: MT-32 reverb level[CR]# Possible values: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.[CR]# mt32.partials: MT-32 max partials allowed (0-256)[CR]mpu401=intelligent[CR]mididevice=default[CR]midiconfig=[CR]samplerate=44100[CR]mpuirq=-1[CR]mt32.reverse.stereo=off[CR]mt32.verbose=off[CR]mt32.thread=off[CR]mt32.dac=auto[CR]mt32.reverb.mode=auto[CR]mt32.reverb.time=5[CR]mt32.reverb.level=3[CR]mt32.partials=32[CR][CR][debug][CR][CR][sblaster][CR]# sbtype: Type of Soundblaster to emulate. gb is Gameblaster.[CR]# Possible values: sb1, sb2, sbpro1, sbpro2, sb16, sb16vibra, gb, ess688, reveal_sc400, none.[CR]# sbbase: The IO address of the soundblaster.[CR]# Possible values: 220, 240, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0, 2e0, 300.[CR]# irq: The IRQ number of the soundblaster. Set to -1 to start DOSBox with the IRQ unassigned[CR]# Possible values: 7, 5, 3, 9, 10, 11, 12.[CR]# mindma: Minimum DMA transfer left to increase attention across DSP blocks, in milliseconds. Set to -1 for default.[CR]# There are some DOS games/demos that use single-cycle DSP playback in their music tracker and they micromanage[CR]# the DMA transfer per block poorly in a way that causes popping and artifacts. Setting this option to 0 for[CR]# such DOS applications may reduce audible popping and artifacts.[CR]# irq hack: Specify a hack related to the Sound Blaster IRQ to avoid crashes in a handful of games and demos.[CR]# none Emulate IRQs normally[CR]# cs_equ_ds Do not fire IRQ unless two CPU segment registers match: CS == DS. Read Dosbox-X Wiki or source code for details.[CR]# dma: The DMA number of the soundblaster. Set to -1 to start DOSBox with the IRQ unassigned[CR]# Possible values: 1, 5, 0, 3, 6, 7.[CR]# hdma: The High DMA number of the soundblaster. Set to -1 to start DOSBox with the IRQ unassigned[CR]# Possible values: 1, 5, 0, 3, 6, 7.[CR]# pic unmask irq: Start the DOS virtual machine with the sound blaster IRQ already unmasked at the PIC.[CR]# Some early DOS games/demos that support Sound Blaster expect the IRQ to fire but make[CR]# no attempt to unmask the IRQ. If audio cuts out no matter what IRQ you try, then try[CR]# setting this option.[CR]# Option is needed for:[CR]# Public NMI "jump" demo (1992)[CR]# enable speaker: Start the DOS virtual machine with the sound blaster speaker enabled.[CR]# Sound Blaster Pro and older cards have a speaker disable/enable command.[CR]# Normally the card boots up with the speaker disabled. If a DOS game or demo[CR]# attempts to play without enabling the speaker, set this option to true to[CR]# compensate. This setting has no meaning if emulating a Sound Blaster 16 card.[CR]# enable asp: If set, emulate the presence of the Sound Blaster 16 Advanced Sound Processor/Creative Sound Processor chip.[CR]# NOTE: This only emulates it's presence and the basic DSP commands to communicate with it. Actual ASP/CSP functions are not yet implemented.[CR]# disable filtering: By default DOSBox-X filters Sound Blaster output to emulate lowpass filters and analog output limitations.[CR]# Set this option to true to disable filtering. Note that doing so disables emulation of the Sound Blaster Pro[CR]# output filter and ESS AudioDrive lowpass filter.[CR]# dsp write buffer status must return 0x7f or 0xff: If set, force port 22Ch (DSP write buffer status) to return 0x7F or 0xFF. If not set, the port[CR]# may return 0x7F or 0xFF depending on what type of Sound Blaster is being emulated.[CR]# Set this option for some early DOS demos that make that assumption about port 22Ch.[CR]# Option is needed for:[CR]# Overload by Hysteria (1992) - Audio will crackle/saturate (8-bit overflow) except when sbtype=sb16[CR]# pre-set sbpro stereo: Start the DOS virtual machine with the Sound Blaster Pro stereo bit set (in the mixer).[CR]# A few demos support Sound Blaster Pro but forget to set this bit.[CR]# Option is needed for:[CR]# Inconexia by Iguana (1993)[CR]# sbmixer: Allow the soundblaster mixer to modify the DOSBox mixer.[CR]# oplmode: Type of OPL emulation. On 'auto' the mode is determined by sblaster type.[CR]# To emulate Adlib, set sbtype=none and oplmode=opl2. To emulate a Game Blaster, set[CR]# sbtype=none and oplmode=cms[CR]# Possible values: auto, cms, opl2, dualopl2, opl3, none, hardware, hardwaregb.[CR]# adlib force timer overflow on detect: If set, Adlib/OPL emulation will signal 'overflow' on timers after 50 I/O reads.[CR]# This is a temporary hack to work around timing bugs noted in DOSBox-X. Certain[CR]# games (Wolfenstein 3D) poll the Adlib status port a fixed number of times assuming[CR]# that the poll loop takes long enough for the Adlib timer to run out. If the game[CR]# cannot reliably detect Adlib at higher cycles counts, but can reliably detect at[CR]# lower cycles counts, set this option.[CR]# NOTE: Technically this decreases emulation accuracy, however it also reflects the[CR]# fact that DOSBox-X's I/O timing code needs some work to better match the[CR]# slowness of the ISA bus per I/O read in consideration of DOS games. So this[CR]# option is ON by default.[CR]# oplemu: Provider for the OPL emulation. compat might provide better quality (see oplrate as well).[CR]# Possible values: default, compat, fast, nuked.[CR]# oplrate: Sample rate of OPL music emulation. Use 49716 for highest quality (set the mixer rate accordingly).[CR]# Possible values: 44100, 49716, 48000, 32000, 22050, 16000, 11025, 8000.[CR]# hardwarebase: base address of the real hardware soundblaster:[CR]# 210,220,230,240,250,260,280[CR]# force dsp auto-init: Treat all single-cycle DSP commands as auto-init to keep playback going.[CR]# This option is a workaround for DOS games or demos that use single-cycle DSP playback commands and[CR]# have problems with missing the Sound Blaster IRQ under load. Do not enable unless you need this workaround.[CR]# Needed for:[CR]# - Extreme "lunatic" demo (1993)[CR]# force goldplay: Always render Sound Blaster output sample-at-a-time. Testing option. You probably don't want to enable this.[CR]# goldplay: Enable goldplay emulation.[CR]# goldplay stereo: Enable workaround for goldplay stereo playback. Many DOS demos using this technique[CR]# don't seem to know they need to double the frequency when programming the DSP time constant for Pro stereo output.[CR]# If stereo playback seems to have artifacts consider enabling this option. For accurate emulation of Sound Blaster[CR]# hardware, disable this option.[CR]# dsp require interrupt acknowledge: If set, the DSP will halt DMA playback until IRQ acknowledgement occurs even in auto-init mode (SB16 behavior).[CR]# If clear, IRQ acknowledgement will have no effect on auto-init playback (SB Pro and earlier & clone behavior)[CR]# If set to 'auto' then behavior is determined by sbtype= setting.[CR]# This is a setting for hardware accuracy in emulation. If audio briefly plays then stops then your DOS game[CR]# and it's not using IRQ (but using DMA), try setting this option to 'false'[CR]# dsp write busy delay: Amount of time in nanoseconds the DSP chip signals 'busy' after writing to the DSP (port 2xCh). Set to -1 to use card-specific defaults.[CR]# WARNING: Setting the value too high (above 20000ns) may have detrimental effects to DOS games that use IRQ 0 and DSP command 0x10 to play audio.[CR]# Setting the value way too high (above 1000000ns) can cause significant lag in DOS games.[CR]# blaster environment variable: Whether or not to set the BLASTER environment variable automatically at startup[CR]# sample rate limits: If set (default), limit DSP sample rate to what real hardware is limited to[CR]# instant direct dac: If set, direct DAC output commands are instantaneous. This option is intended as a quick fix for[CR]# games or demos that play direct DAC music/sound from the IRQ 0 timer who a) write the DSP command[CR]# and data without polling the DSP to ensure it's ready or b) can get locked into the IRQ 0 handler[CR]# waiting for DSP status when instructed to play at or beyond the DSP's maximum direct DAC sample rate.[CR]# This fix allows broken Sound Blaster code to work and should not be enabled unless necessary.[CR]# stereo control with sbpro only: Default on. If set, Sound Blaster Pro stereo is not available when emulating sb16 or sb16vibra.[CR]# If clear, sb16 emulation will honor the sbpro stereo bit. Note that Creative SB16 cards do not[CR]# honor the stereo bit, and this option allows DOSBox emulate that fact. Accuracy setting.[CR]# dsp busy cycle rate: Sound Blaster 16 DSP chips appear to go busy periodically at some high clock rate[CR]# whether the DSP is actually doing anything for the system or not. This is an accuracy[CR]# option for Sound Blaster emulation. If this option is nonzero, it will be interpreted[CR]# as the busy cycle rate in Hz. If zero, busy cycle will not be emulated. If -1, sound[CR]# blaster emulation will automatically choose a setting based on the sbtype= setting[CR]# dsp busy cycle always: If set, the DSP busy cycle always happens. If clear, DSP busy cycle only happens when[CR]# audio playback is running. Default setting is to pick according to the sound card.[CR]# dsp busy cycle duty: If emulating SB16 busy cycle, this value (0 to 100) controls the duty cycle of the busy cycle.[CR]# If this option is set to -1, Sound Blaster emulation will choose a value automatically according[CR]# to sbtype=. If 0, busy cycle emulation is disabled.[CR]# io port aliasing: If set, Sound Blaster ports alias by not decoding the LSB of the I/O port.[CR]# This option only applies when sbtype is set to sb1 or sb2 (not SBPro or SB16).[CR]# This is a hack for the Electromotive Force 'Internal Damage' demo which apparently[CR]# relies on this behavior for Sound Blaster output and should be enabled for accuracy in rate=-1[CR]dsp busy cycle always=-1[CR]dsp busy cycle duty=-1[CR]io port aliasing=true[CR][CR][gus][CR]# gus: Enable the Gravis Ultrasound emulation.[CR]# autoamp: If set, GF1 output will reduce in volume automatically if the sum of all channels exceeds full volume.[CR]# If not set, then loud music will clip to full volume just as it would on real hardware.[CR]# Enable this option for loud music if you want a more pleasing rendition without saturation and distortion.[CR]# unmask dma: Start the DOS virtual machine with the DMA channel already unmasked at the controller.[CR]# Use this for DOS applications that expect to operate the GUS but forget to unmask the DMA channel.[CR]# pic unmask irq: Start the DOS virtual machine with the GUS IRQ already unmasked at the PIC.[CR]# startup initialized: If set, start the GF1 in a fully initialized state (as if ULTRINIT had been run).[CR]# If clear, leave the card in an uninitialized state (as if cold boot).[CR]# Some DOS games or demoscene productions will hang or fail to use the Ultrasound hardware[CR]# because they assume the card is initialized and their hardware detect does not fully initialize the card.[CR]# dma enable on dma control polling: If set, automatically enable GUS DMA transfer bit in specific cases when the DMA control register is being polled.[CR]# THIS IS A HACK. Some games and demoscene productions need this hack to avoid hanging while uploading sample data[CR]# to the Gravis Ultrasound due to bugs in their implementation.[CR]# clear dma tc irq if excess polling: If the DOS application is seen polling the IRQ status register rapidly, automatically clear the DMA TC IRQ status.[CR]# This is a hack that should only be used with DOS applications that need it to avoid bugs in their GUS support code.[CR]# Needed for:[CR]# Warcraft II by Blizzard ............. if using GUS for music and sound, set this option to prevent the game from[CR]# hanging when you click on the buttons in the main menu.[CR]# force master irq enable: Set this option if a DOS game or demo initializes the GUS but is unable to play any music.[CR]# Usually the cause is buggy GUS support that resets the GUS but fails to set the Master IRQ enable bit.[CR]# gus panning table: Controls which table or equation is used for the Gravis Ultrasound panning emulation.[CR]# accurate emulation attempts to better reflect how the actual hardware handles panning,[CR]# while the old emulation uses a simpler idealistic mapping.[CR]# Possible values: old, accurate, default.[CR]# gusrate: Sample rate of Ultrasound emulation.[CR]# Possible values: 44100, 48000, 32000, 22050, 16000, 11025, 8000, 49716.[CR]# gus fixed render rate: If set, Gravis Ultrasound audio output is rendered at a fixed sample rate specified by 'gusrate'. This can provide better quality than real hardware,[CR]# if desired. Else, Gravis Ultrasound emulation will change the sample rate of it's output according to the number of active channels, just like real hardware.[CR]# Note: DOSBox-X defaults to 'false', while mainline DOSBox SVN is currently hardcoded to render as if this setting is 'true'.[CR]# gusmemsize: Amount of RAM on the Gravis Ultrasound in KB. Set to -1 for default.[CR]# gus master volume: Master Gravis Ultrasound GF1 volume, in decibels. Reducing the master volume can help with games or demoscene productions where the music is too loud and clipping[CR]# gusbase: The IO base address of the Gravis Ultrasound.[CR]# Possible values: 240, 220, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0, 2e0, 300, 210, 230, 250.[CR]# gusirq: The IRQ number of the Gravis Ultrasound.[CR]# Possible values: 5, 3, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12.[CR]# gusdma: The DMA channel of the Gravis Ultrasound.[CR]# Possible values: 3, 0, 1, 5, 6, 7.[CR]# irq hack: Specify a hack related to the Gravis Ultrasound IRQ to avoid crashes in a handful of games and demos.[CR]# none Emulate IRQs normally[CR]# cs_equ_ds Do not fire IRQ unless two CPU segment registers match: CS == DS. Read Dosbox-X Wiki or source code for details.[CR]# gustype: Type of Gravis Ultrasound to emulate.[CR]# classic Original Gravis Ultrasound chipset[CR]# classic37 Original Gravis Ultrasound with ICS Mixer (rev 3.7)[CR]# max Gravis Ultrasound MAX emulation (with CS4231 codec)[CR]# interwave Gravis Ultrasound Plug & Play (interwave)[CR]# Possible values: classic, classic37, max, interwave.[CR]# ultradir: Path to Ultrasound directory. In this directory[CR]# there should be a MIDI directory that contains[CR]# the patch files for GUS playback.
